JS_BEGINNER_DESC: Learn JavaScript from zero to hero — step by step, with fun challenges!
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_0_DESC:
JavaScript Basics Tutorial
JavaScript is a programming language that allows you to program computers.

1. Comments To make the computer take a note, use //. 
// A comment starts with //
// The computer does not execute anything that starts with //
// This is just for you to comment on what your code does

2. Displaying Texts and Numbers To make the computer display texts, use console.log():
console.log("Welcome")
To display numbers:
console.log(100)

3. Variables To store text or numbers, use let:
let name = "Ali";
let age = 20;

4. Functions This function adds two numbers:
function add(a, b) {
   return a + b;
}
To call the function:
let result = add(x, y);

5. Condition Statements Example using if and else:
let a = 20;
let b = 2;

if (a > b) {
   console.log("a is greater than b")
} else {
    console.log("a is less than b")
}

6. Arrays To store multiple items, use arrays:
let myeggs = [];
With initial values:
let ages = [10, 22];
let shelf = ["book", "fruit", "bottle"];
Access values:
console.log(ages[1]); // 10
console.log(shelf[2]); // bottle
Length property:
console.log(myeggs.length);
console.log(shelf.length);

7. Loops Repeating actions with a for...of loop:
for (let drawer of shelf) {
    console.log(drawer);
}

JavaScript is an evolving language with rich features that you will explore in the upcoming tutorials.
In this tutorial, you learned about what JavaScript is and gained an overview of the JavaScript language.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_1_DESC: Make the computer greet the user by displaying 'Assalam Alaykum'.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_2_DESC: Make the computer display its name.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_2_INITIAL: // TODO: Make the computer say its name
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_2_HINT_2: Combine text with the computer's name.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_2_HINT_3: Try writing the exact sentence in quotes.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_3_DESC: Store the computer's name and age in variables.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_3_HINT_3: Strings are in quotes, numbers are not.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_4_DESC: Store items in room cupboard, kitchen cupboard, and contacts.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_4_INITIAL: // TODO: Create arrays for cupboards and contacts
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_4_HINT_1: Use square brackets [] to create arrays.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_4_HINT_3: Numbers do not need quotes, strings do.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_5_DESC: Ask the computer to compare its age with yours and display a message.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_5_HINT_1: Use if, else if, else for conditions.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_5_HINT_3: console.log() can display different messages depending on the age.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_6_DESC: Make the computer say its name 5 times using a loop.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_6_HINT_2: Start i at 0, loop while i < 5, increase i each time.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_6_HINT_3: Use + to combine text and variables.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_7_DESC: Make the computer display all items in the room cupboard using a loop.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_7_HINT_1: Use a for...of loop to go through an array.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_7_HINT_2: Each item in the array can be printed using console.log()
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_7_HINT_3: You can call each item 'drawer' or any name.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_8_DESC: Display the total number of items in each cupboard and contacts.
JS_BEGINNER_TASK_8_HINT_1: Use array.length to get the number of items.
AJMJS_BEGINNER_DESC: Learn JavaScript from zero to hero — step by step, with fun challenges!
AJMJS_BEGINNER_TASK_0_DESC:
DialectScript Basics Tutorial
DialectScript is a programming language that allows you to program computers.

1. Comments To make the computer take a note, use //. 
// A comment starts with //
// The computer does not execute anything that starts with //
// This is just for you to comment on what your code does

2. Displaying Texts and Numbers To make the computer display texts, use rubuta():
rubuta("Sannu da zuwa")
To display numbers:
rubuta(100)

3. Variables To store text or numbers, use madadi:
madadi suna = "Ali";
madadi shekara = 20;

4. Aiki This function adds two numbers:
aiki add(a, b) {
   return a + b;
}
To call the function:
madadi result = add(x, y);

5. Condition Statements Example using idan and kokuma:
madadi a = 20;
madadi b = 2;

idan (a > b) {
   rubuta("a is greater than b")
} kokuma {
    rubuta("a is less than b")
}

6. Arrays To store multiple items, use arrays:
madadi myeggs = [];
With initial values:
madadi shekaru = [10, 22];
madadi shelf = ["book", "fruit", "bottle"];
Access values:
rubuta(shekaru[1]); // 10
rubuta(shelf[2]); // bottle
Length property:
rubuta(myeggs.tsawo);
rubuta(shelf.tsawo);

7. Loops Repeating actions with a faraDaga..kowanef loop:
faraDaga (madadi drawer kowane shelf) {
    rubuta(drawer);
}

DialectScript is an evolving language with rich features that you will explore in the upcoming tutorials.
In this tutorial, you learned about what DialectScript is and gained an overview of the DialectScript language.
